name.description: Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures

mods.abstract: As a fiction writer, Lev Tolstoi is most famous for strategies for the authorial domination of material, manipulative techniques like interior monologue, ostranenie (defamiliarization), absolute language, and massive particularization in the pursuit of first causes, which give a writer great leeway for a variety of interpretive and debunking projects. After his crisis, however, this invasive, totalizing fiction recedes not fully into, but very much towards, silence. Fiction is no longer the writer’s main focus; the fictions he does write are fewer in number, shorter in length, their topics treated with limited analytical depth-just enough and no more.’ This silence that besets the imaginative literature derives from a tension with ethics. Fiction writing is relativizing, self-aggrandizing, fundamentally biased towards the shallowly entertaining, pen-pushing when deeds are called for, and a host of other bad things. Late in life, however, the author undertakes a literary experiment, bold even, or rather especially, by his own standards.

originInfo.publisher: The American Association for the Advancement of Slavic Studies
